entry.value: This page features some of the more uncommon controls in Rapid that can still alter the feel of your apps.

The controls covered on this page are more of the lesser used controls, but still hold a strong amount of relevance for a multitude of different apps within Rapid. Even on this demo app you will find controls on this page have made multiple appearances already! This page will go into detail on these controls and will hopefully give you a better understanding on how they work and how to use them in your Rapid applications, whenever and wherever they are needed.

The first control we are going to cover is the grid control. We have used this control throughout the data copy pages, as they are most used with data copies in Rapid. The grid control's main purpose is to display data that is relayed from other sources, be it datastores, controls in Rapid, or be populated through logic on the page.
// This page is temporary and will change in full puplication open("~?a=demo&v=3&p=P6", "_blank");

The next control we are going to cover is a less graphical version of the grid control, the table control! Whilst the grid control builds from the table, the table control has other roles assigned to it other than displaying data from one place to another in a stylistic way. The table control is able to have other controls inside of it, and can have each cell, row and table as a whole customised to make it have a unique feel. The table control is also how most of this demo app has been laid out! For this example we have made the table visible with some simple CSS.

This next control is something similar to the datestore control, in that it appears fixed in the bottom left of the page when you have design privileges. The hint control is used to show information to users in a discrete, unobtrusive way. Hints can be attached to a lot of controls in Rapid, and you may have noticed that we have been using them for quite some time throughout this application! The showing of hints can be done through either hovering over a control or clicking the control. For mobile developers, clicking will be more useful as you cannot hover with current mobile and tablet devices.

The next control we are going to cover on this page is the Tabs control. Each tab can contain any of the other controls Rapid has to offer, and the tab control itself can have as many or as little tabs as you need it to have. Tabs can be aligned vertically or horizontally. The Tabs control are featured most effectively in Rapid Admin.

I am an example of a control that can exist within the Tabs control! Each tab can contain almost every other control in Rapid, including another Tabs control. Rapid Admin is a good example on how to use the Tabs control effectively.

Clicking on another tab will take you to the respective tab, which will show something different. As tabs are able to pull in data from external sources it can be useful in combination with the page load event, or click event on a button, in order to populate many controls used throughout different tabs.
Rate how you are feeling today

One thing that is worth keeping an eye on is what tab you save on. Rapid will remember what tab is selected when you hit Save in the Rapid Designer and that tab will be the first visible tab when the page loads.

The final control on this page we are going to cover is the charts control. Like with the date control, the chart control has recently gone through an upgrade, with the assistance of the Google libraries for charts. Charts are an interesting control that can display data in the forms of pie charts, bar charts, and line graphs. It is worth keeping in mind that graphs need data in order to be useful within Rapid.

Each type of chart in Rapid has it's own unique options. Pie charts have a lot of positioning options that change the location of where the pie chart is situated within it's control radius. The position and alignment of the legend, or key, can also be defined, or disabled entirely. Each slice of the pie chart can have the amount listed in percentage, a standard value, a label, or hidden. Each slice can also be customised with a different colour. If no colours are set then it will use the default colours set. An option for 3D is also available for pie charts, giving it that extra dimension to help it stand out. The last option for the pie charts is when to group similar results together under a single 'Other' slice. This is useful for when you have multiple, small entries.
The line graph has the same options regarding positioning, colour, and legends to the pie chart, however there is the option to make the jagged lines curved instead.

Similar to the pie chart and line graph before it, the bar chart has the same options for positioning, colouring, and legend positions. Similar to the line graph, it has it's own unique option as well. For the bar graph it has the option of stacking bars together, used to place multiple series into a single column.

With our lesser used controls covered we can now show you some of Rapid's form capabilities. Whilst Rapid is mainly an application builder, it can create forms as well! A good example of a detailed form is Camden's housing application, and you can find information on that by clicking the link below. We will also link the forms part of this demo for you to explore and examine, to get you better accustomed to more of what Rapid can provide.

[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C39_","text":"For the purposes of this page we have set a database action on the page load that builds data into the grid control on the page.
This is just one simple way in which to use the grid control. When copying into the grid control it is important to note that
the fields must match up from source to destination in order for data to be successfully copied. For more ways on how to use
the grid control in your Rapid application click on this link to go to the page on data copy types.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C49_","text":"You may find that the table control can be a little hard to add new rows to, however it can be done very easily. If a row
is selected you can add another by clicking on the arrow with a plus by it in the Rapid Designer, shown in the top right
corner in the properties menu. If a cell is selected you can add an individual cell to the row by clicking the same button.
You must have access to the Rapid Designer in order to carry this out.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C72_","text":"Clicking on this button will restore the grid's original information if it has had it's data replaced.
I have been generated using the hint control!","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C74_","text":"Text for hints can be freely set and adjusted at any time in the Rapid Designer. Each hint can have it's own
style rules applied to it, be set to appear on hover or click, and can be attached to many different visible
controls on your Rapid app page. As with everything in Rapid, it can be completely adjusted using CSS. Each
theme in Rapid will also display hints slightly differently to suit the look and feel of that specific theme.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C79_","text":"Tabs are a nice way of showing a range of information without loading another page in Rapid. Each tab has the
capability of storing and reading data from other sources such as databases, and have them in memory ready to
display as and when they are needed to be shown on the screen. Each tab has it's own unique ID that can be
referenced and used in custom javascript code. Like with all Rapid controls, the tabs can be completely
customised using CSS and has a different feel for each theme available.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C184_","text":"The pie chart is easily the most graphically intensive of the trio of chart types, especially if 3D is used.
Pie charts can be used to show data in a very graphically pleasing manner. There are different occasions regarding
when it is best to use a pie chart, over the other types, however if you have a fair amount of data and a good
colour spectrum to use then the pie chart suits those needs best.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C185_","text":"Sporting a more minimalistic design when compared to the other chart types, the line graph is brilliant and
showcasing a range of different results. Generally line graphs are best used when there is a long range of data
to display. Curving the lines can be useful if the jagged edges are not quite up to aesthetic standards.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C186_","text":"Bar charts are a good middle ground when covering data. They have more of a graphical presence than line charts, and they are not
as bulky, or data intensive with 3D, as pie charts. As all chart types support the same options, minus one unique option, the
choice of which one to use is entirely up to you. It is very easy to insert more chart controls, have them display the same data in
the same manner, and line them up side by side in a live environment. This is the beauty of Rapid, being able to jump back and
forth between a development environment and a live environment.","type":"hover"}]

{"controlHints":[{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C39_","text":"For the purposes of this page we have set a database action on the page load that builds data into the grid control on the page.
This is just one simple way in which to use the grid control. When copying into the grid control it is important to note that
the fields must match up from source to destination in order for data to be successfully copied. For more ways on how to use
the grid control in your Rapid application click on this link to go to the page on data copy types.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C49_","text":"You may find that the table control can be a little hard to add new rows to, however it can be done very easily. If a row
is selected you can add another by clicking on the arrow with a plus by it in the Rapid Designer, shown in the top right
corner in the properties menu. If a cell is selected you can add an individual cell to the row by clicking the same button.
You must have access to the Rapid Designer in order to carry this out.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C72_","text":"Clicking on this button will restore the grid's original information if it has had it's data replaced.
I have been generated using the hint control!","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C74_","text":"Text for hints can be freely set and adjusted at any time in the Rapid Designer. Each hint can have it's own
style rules applied to it, be set to appear on hover or click, and can be attached to many different visible
controls on your Rapid app page. As with everything in Rapid, it can be completely adjusted using CSS. Each
theme in Rapid will also display hints slightly differently to suit the look and feel of that specific theme.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C79_","text":"Tabs are a nice way of showing a range of information without loading another page in Rapid. Each tab has the
capability of storing and reading data from other sources such as databases, and have them in memory ready to
display as and when they are needed to be shown on the screen. Each tab has it's own unique ID that can be
referenced and used in custom javascript code. Like with all Rapid controls, the tabs can be completely
customised using CSS and has a different feel for each theme available.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C184_","text":"The pie chart is easily the most graphically intensive of the trio of chart types, especially if 3D is used.
Pie charts can be used to show data in a very graphically pleasing manner. There are different occasions regarding
when it is best to use a pie chart, over the other types, however if you have a fair amount of data and a good
colour spectrum to use then the pie chart suits those needs best.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C185_","text":"Sporting a more minimalistic design when compared to the other chart types, the line graph is brilliant and
showcasing a range of different results. Generally line graphs are best used when there is a long range of data
to display. Curving the lines can be useful if the jagged edges are not quite up to aesthetic standards.","type":"hover"},{"style":"max-width: 400px;","controlId":"P21_C186_","text":"Bar charts are a good middle ground when covering data. They have more of a graphical presence than line charts, and they are not
as bulky, or data intensive with 3D, as pie charts. As all chart types support the same options, minus one unique option, the
choice of which one to use is entirely up to you. It is very easy to insert more chart controls, have them display the same data in
the same manner, and line them up side by side in a live environment. This is the beauty of Rapid, being able to jump back and
forth between a development environment and a live environment.","type":"hover"}]}

query.SQL: select forename, surname, birthday, gender from people where id > 3 and id < 5 or id > 56 and id < 60 or id > 112 and id < 118 order by RANDOM()

select case (strftime('%Y', 'now') - strftime('%Y', birthday)) / 10
when 0 then 'Less than 10' when 1 then '10 to 19' when 2 then '20 to 29' when 3 then '30 to 39' when 4 then '40 to 49' when 5 then '50 to 59' when 6 then '60 to 69' when 7 then '70 to 79' when 8 then '80 to 89' when 9 then '90 to 99' else 'Over 100'
end "Age band",
sum(case when gender = 'M' then 1 end) "Number of men",
sum(case when gender = 'F' then 1 end) "Number of women"
from people group by 1

select case (strftime('%Y', 'now') - strftime('%Y', birthday)) / 10
when 0 then 'Less than 10' when 1 then '10 to 19' when 2 then '20 to 29' when 3 then '30 to 39' when 4 then '40 to 49' when 5 then '50 to 59' when 6 then '60 to 69' when 7 then '70 to 79' when 8 then '80 to 89' when 9 then '90 to 99' else 'Over 100'
end "Age band",
sum(case when gender = 'M' then 1 end) "Number of men",
sum(case when gender = 'F' then 1 end) "Number of women"
from people group by 1

select case gender
when 'F' then 'Female'
when 'M' then 'Male'
end "Gender",
count(*) "Number of people"
from people
group by gender

page.htmlBody:
This page features some of the more uncommon controls in Rapid that can still alter the feel of your apps.

The controls covered on this page are more of the lesser used controls, but still hold a strong amount of relevance for a multitude of different apps within Rapid. Even on this demo app you will find controls on this page have made multiple appearances already! This page will go into detail on these controls and will hopefully give you a better understanding on how they work and how to use them in your Rapid applications, whenever and wherever they are needed.The first control we are going to cover is the grid control. We have used this control throughout the data copy pages, as they are most used with data copies in Rapid. The grid control's main purpose is to display data that is relayed from other sources, be it datastores, controls in Rapid, or be populated through logic on the page.
ForenameSurnameAgeGender
The next control we are going to cover is a less graphical version of the grid control, the table control! Whilst the grid control builds from the table, the table control has other roles assigned to it other than displaying data from one place to another in a stylistic way. The table control is able to have other controls inside of it, and can have each cell, row and table as a whole customised to make it have a unique feel. The table control is also how most of this demo app has been laid out! For this example we have made the table visible with some simple CSS.
Sample data: Forename
Sample data: Surname
Sample data: Age
Sample data: Gender
This next control is something similar to the datestore control, in that it appears fixed in the bottom left of the page when you have design privileges. The hint control is used to show information to users in a discrete, unobtrusive way. Hints can be attached to a lot of controls in Rapid, and you may have noticed that we have been using them for quite some time throughout this application! The showing of hints can be done through either hovering over a control or clicking the control. For mobile developers, clicking will be more useful as you cannot hover with current mobile and tablet devices.
The next control we are going to cover on this page is the Tabs control. Each tab can contain any of the other controls Rapid has to offer, and the tab control itself can have as many or as little tabs as you need it to have. Tabs can be aligned vertically or horizontally. The Tabs control are featured most effectively in Rapid Admin.
  • Sample tab 1
  • Sample tab 2
  • Sample tab 3
I am an example of a control that can exist within the Tabs control! Each tab can contain almost every other control in Rapid, including another Tabs control. Rapid Admin is a good example on how to use the Tabs control effectively.Clicking on another tab will take you to the respective tab, which will show something different. As tabs are able to pull in data from external sources it can be useful in combination with the page load event, or click event on a button, in order to populate many controls used throughout different tabs.
Rate how you are feeling today1234567
Name
Version
Status
Description
One thing that is worth keeping an eye on is what tab you save on. Rapid will remember what tab is selected when you hit Save in the Rapid Designer and that tab will be the first visible tab when the page loads.
The final control on this page we are going to cover is the charts control. Like with the date control, the chart control has recently gone through an upgrade, with the assistance of the Google libraries for charts. Charts are an interesting control that can display data in the forms of pie charts, bar charts, and line graphs. It is worth keeping in mind that graphs need data in order to be useful within Rapid.
Each type of chart in Rapid has it's own unique options. Pie charts have a lot of positioning options that change the location of where the pie chart is situated within it's control radius. The position and alignment of the legend, or key, can also be defined, or disabled entirely. Each slice of the pie chart can have the amount listed in percentage, a standard value, a label, or hidden. Each slice can also be customised with a different colour. If no colours are set then it will use the default colours set. An option for 3D is also available for pie charts, giving it that extra dimension to help it stand out. The last option for the pie charts is when to group similar results together under a single 'Other' slice. This is useful for when you have multiple, small entries.
The line graph has the same options regarding positioning, colour, and legends to the pie chart, however there is the option to make the jagged lines curved instead.
Similar to the pie chart and line graph before it, the bar chart has the same options for positioning, colouring, and legend positions. Similar to the line graph, it has it's own unique option as well. For the bar graph it has the option of stacking bars together, used to place multiple series into a single column.
With our lesser used controls covered we can now show you some of Rapid's form capabilities. Whilst Rapid is mainly an application builder, it can create forms as well! A good example of a detailed form is Camden's housing application, and you can find information on that by clicking the link below. We will also link the forms part of this demo for you to explore and examine, to get you better accustomed to more of what Rapid can provide.
Camden housing application showcaseRapid forms demo
page.name: 27_rapidControls3

rolesHtml.html:
This page features some of the more uncommon controls in Rapid that can still alter the feel of your apps.

The controls covered on this page are more of the lesser used controls, but still hold a strong amount of relevance for a multitude of different apps within Rapid. Even on this demo app you will find controls on this page have made multiple appearances already! This page will go into detail on these controls and will hopefully give you a better understanding on how they work and how to use them in your Rapid applications, whenever and wherever they are needed.The first control we are going to cover is the grid control. Sample data: Surname
Sample data: Age

Similar to the pie chart and line graph before it, the bar chart has the same options for positioning, colouring, and legend positions. page.title: Uncommon controls
